title: Lizzo is '100%' our style icon amid Truth Hurts 'plagiarism' claims
text:
Nobody puts Lizzo in the corner (Picture: Kevin Winter/Getty Images for RADIO.COM)

Lizzo put her best foot forward on Saturday as she performed at the Hollywood Bowl for the 7th Annual I Will Survive show.

And the star seemed determined to fight back after being hit with new plagiarism accusations over her hit single Truth Hurts in the way she does best: with a seriously impressive outfit and those singing pipes.

Giving us major James Bond vibes (here’s hoping she’s in the running for the No Time To Die theme tune), the 31-year-old singer looked stunning in a white, cropped collared shirt worn with a black neck tie.

However, it was the singer’s pair of sparkly, pinstriped trousers which caused particular waves, as the star wore her heart on her sleeve. Or, erm, on her leg.

Emblazoned with a sequinned ‘100%’ symbol on the leg and ‘that b****’ on the back, the detailing was a thinly veiled reference to Truth Hurts’ iconic opening line, ‘I just took a DNA test, turns out I’m 100% that b****,’ which is at the centre of the scandal.

Earlier this week Lizzo’s 2017 single – which became a sleeper hit after re-entering the charts this year – was the subject of scandal after songwriter and producer Justin Raisen claimed to have written the lyric.

Issa look (Picture: Kevin Winter/Getty Images for RADIO.COM )

We’re obsessed (Picture: Kevin Winter/Getty Images for RADIO.COM)

With her dance group The Big Grrrls (Picture: Kevin Winter/Getty Images for RADIO.COM)

Justin took to Instagram to post a comparison video of the start of Truth Hurts and a song he and others co-wrote with Lizzo called Healthy, with both songs featuring the lyric and a similar tune.

‘In April 11th, 2017, we wrote a song called Healthy w/ Lizzo, Jesse St John, and Yves Rothman at our studio,’ he wrote.

‘“I just took a DNA test turns out I’m 100% that bitch” was taken from Healthy and used in Truth Hurts.

‘We were never contacted about being credited for the use of the parts of Healthy (melody, lyrics, and chords) that appear in Truth Hurts.’

He continued: ‘The last thing we want to do is throw any negativity toward Lizzo’s momentum and movement as a cultural figure. If we believe in what she’s preaching, believing in ourselves & our own voices is something we thought she’d understand.’

In a statement to the New York Times, Lizzo’s lawyer denied their claims, saying: ‘The Raisens are not writers of Truth Hurts.

‘They did not help write any of the material that they now seek to profit from, which is why they expressly renounced any claim to the work, in writing, months ago.’
